explanation: Assignment operators in C are used to assign values to variables.  They take a value on the right-hand side and store it into the variable on the left-hand side.  This is fundamental for manipulating data within a C program.
code_example: x = 10; // Assigns the value 10 to variable x
y = x + 5; // Assigns the result of x + 5 (15) to y
example_explanation: This example demonstrates the basic assignment operator (=).  It first assigns the integer value 10 to the variable `x`. Then, it calculates `x + 5` (which equals 15) and assigns this result to the variable `y`. Finally, it prints the values of `x` and `y` to the console, showing the effect of the assignments.

extraction_metadata.source: The C Programming Language - Kernighan & Ritchie
